reviewText:
Edit:
I'd ignore that one negative review. Guy seems butthurt that he couldn't beat it or something. The trading card feature is working, based off of the fact there's some already out in the market and the fact that I just unlocked one.

Sure there's better puzzle games out there, but this is a dollar. That's like going to Taco Bell and saying there is better tacos out there. This game is very, very challenging and if you actually like puzzles and a challenge you should get it.

Original:

This one is actually more challenging than the first, and just as good, if not better.

I can't stress this enough, but this game is worth more than the price of $1, and is definitely worth it at the release discount.

You're just moving a jiggly cube around to hit other jiggly cubes and get them into a square on the ground, but the actual puzzles are pretty complicated. Simple concept, great design. I recommend getting the first goo cubletes as well.
voteText: 34 of 54 people (63%) found this review helpful 8 people found this review funny

reviewText: Being not far into the game as of writing, I pretty much see gameplay from GooCubelets 1 with twists added here and there. Sokoban with an innovative idea made first part quite good. Second part is no exception. While there are some annoyances, which include black cubes that kill you when you come in their 3x3 zone, which could just be replaced by walls and nothing would have changed, and a bit repetitive design of some levels which require you to push several cubes SAME long path, the game is pretty much mind blowing and interesting in the way that various game mechanics make the game very tough until you get the feeling of the fact that you can go onto empty space and then move one more tile without falling and until you actually start planning you movements far in advance.\nFor puzzle lovers - take immediately. For people, who frequently is being stuck in puzzle games - stay away, as there is no undo button and trial and error is unwelcome here.\nAnother thing is game price. I wouls say that the developer put pretty honest price here: its around exacly how much the game offers you: there are 50 levels, which are not long, and the game isnt really tough, but level intensity and really good gameplay make up for it more than enough.
voteText: 16 of 24 people (67%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Introduces some new mechanics, but also introduces new ways to get screwed by inconsistent non-grid physics.  You frequently have to skirt your cube along an edge, and sometimes it'll fall off mid-roll.  If you have to push another cube from along an edge or across an angled intersection, sometimes the collision will shove the target half a space to the side, which makes it impossible to interact with along that axis.  Stairs are introduced, but they often end up offsetting your cube by a fraction of a grid space.

Ink cubes will reset the puzzle if any other cube touches their ink stain.  But they're often placed at non-grid intervals, which makes it nearly impossible to predict their death zone without running into it several times.  This is exacerbated by very large levels, which pan the camera out so far that it becomes difficult to even estimate depth and how close you are to one.

On top of that, some of the level design is very lazy, forcing you to navigate several cubes one at a time across the exact same obstacle course with little to no variation.

On the plus side, it's optimized a bit better than the first game.

reviewText: It's about the same as GooCubelets, but with a few new stuff in it to make it a bit more interesting. If you liked the first game, you'll like this one too. In the end, whether I recommend this to you or not comes down to: Did you like the first game?\n\nI did, so I'm hitting that Yes" button."

reviewText:
Considering this is a fairly inexpensive game I don't hold it to high standards - however, despite being the sequel it manages to be worse then GooCubelets".

A few things I had issue with:
- less controller support; for some reason the start button isn't mapped to reset the puzzle like in GooCublets
- had to troubleshoot the graphic for the position marks to show on the puzzles
- most of the puzzles use edge movements which frequently put your block off grid by fragments of a square

The last point is the biggest concern as most of the puzzles have mechanics based on more edge-focused movements which sometimes cause your block to be off grid and it can throw off the whole puzzle.  This was also present in GooCublets but was only an issue in a handful of the later puzzles.

Another mechanic they added was black blocks which cause a fail of you touch them but their area of effect is only indicated by small splash marks which makes navigating around them more challenging for no reason as their "hit box" is invisible in places.

Most of the challenge with this game is just dealing with some of the quirky movement physics rather than the actual block placement puzzles."
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The second Iteration of the Sokoban Transport Puzzle Clone (made with Personal Unity Engine) now even adds more Annoyances like Boxes(GooCubelets) now can falling down, this Annoyance also added some Bugs, like Boxes no more aligned correctly if you go over the Border and quickly back again to avoid falling down, which then makes moving other Boxes impossible.

And now a Main Menu was added in which there is no Controller support, that unfortunately broken the full Controller support the first Iteration of the Game had also the Times are unchanged tight and boring. Still it would perhaps be a nice Game for a Mobile Phone or Tablet, but definitely not for playing on TV.

The large bright-white Background was changed to bright-blue, unfortunately now the large Area where you move the Boxes(GooCubelets) is bright-white and so it's a real pain and still hurts my Night-Creature-Eyes. I would give it a Neutral Rating, but unfortunately Steam only has Thumb up/down, so by applying the typical round down it's a Thumb down.

reviewText:
It was all in that moment when I just sat back and laughed. I couldn't believe it was quite this good. I chuckled in muddled disbelief, expectations utterly defied. My nervous fingers reloaded the level, knowing that I had to see that breathtaking sequence one more time.

It would be madness for me to spoil this game by talking about the specific turn of events, so spoilers are going to be kept to a minimum:

The world is infested with head-crab zombies and the aliens that were once your enemies now co‚Äëexist amongst the oppressed masses. This very European city is populated by frightened and desperate American immigrants, and sits under the shadow of a vast, brutalist skyscraper that is consuming the urban sprawl with crawling walls of blue steel. It's a powerful fiction. The Combine, the military government that controls the city in a boot-stamping-face kind of way, are a clear threat, but quite how they came to be and what their purposes are become aching problems.


This is the one unmissable game. Its time to get that cutting-edge PC system. Sell your grandmother, remortgage the cat, do whatever you have to do. Just dont miss out.

reviewText:
Go to Store (Featured), Click on Games, Narrow by Feature (Steam Trading Cards), Relevance (Lowest Price).
Then skip to Page 9 or 10, until you find the .50 - $1.00 games.
Add them to your Wishlist, games that are a dollar can go on sale and you may be able to purchase for cheap!
A game at .50 may give you that value back in trading cards.
Search and Install Idle Master" which will run your games even without the game being installed.

I may or may not ever play this game
date: but some games I have installed and messed around with on a rainy day!\n@ .50-$1.00 it's hard not to recommend!"
